title: The Treatment Landscape of PNH

content: Treatments for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) can improve your quality of life and longevity. There have been plenty of advancements in PNH treatments in recent years, and more are on the horizon. As of now, the only possible cure for PNH is a bone marrow transplant, which is also called a stem cell transplant. The procedure involves injecting healthy stem cells into your body to eventually make more. But a bone marrow transplant is risky and isn’t right for everyone. That said, there are various treatments available to ease symptoms and prevent more problems from PNH. Many treatments can stop or slow red blood cells from breaking down – a process called hemolysis – which is what can lead to symptoms and complications.

content_blocks.text: Treatments for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) can improve your quality of life and longevity. There have been plenty of advancements in PNH treatments in recent years, and more are on the horizon. As of now, the only possible cure for PNH is a bone marrow transplant, which is also called a stem cell transplant. The procedure involves injecting healthy stem cells into your body to eventually make more. But a bone marrow transplant is risky and isn’t right for everyone. That said, there are various treatments available to ease symptoms and prevent more problems from PNH. Many treatments can stop or slow red blood cells from breaking down – a process called hemolysis – which is what can lead to symptoms and complications.

sections.heading: PNH Treatments
content: After diagnosis, your doctor may advise you not to treat your PNH right away. Instead, you may “watch and wait” to see if it gets worse. Your doctor will monitor your blood work and keep an eye on symptoms like dark-colored pee.

content_blocks.text: After diagnosis, your doctor may advise you not to treat your PNH right away. Instead, you may “watch and wait” to see if it gets worse. Your doctor will monitor your blood work and keep an eye on symptoms like dark-colored pee.

content: If you do treat your PNH, you may get a blood transfusion. This is when you receive a donor’s healthy blood through a needle inserted into your vein. Other treatment options include taking: Iron if you’re not getting enough Folate to help you make more red blood cells Growth factors to boost blood cell growth Blood thinners to lower the chances of blood clots that are common with the disorder Aplastic anemia can occur if you have PNH, so you may need to treat that condition as well. This happens when your bone marrow doesn’t make enough blood cells. Scientists think this happens because your immune system attacks your bone marrow. Your doctor may recommend immunosuppressive drugs like antithymocyte globulin (ATG) and cyclosporine if you have aplastic anemia. Some doctors may suggest taking prednisone to slow red blood cell destruction. Others say it may not work and could be risky. All the treatments listed above used to be the only way to help people with PNH. About 40%-60% of people with PNH used to experience blood clots, or thrombosis, which was a main reason for PNH-related deaths. Loss of kidney function also was a top cause of death in people with PNH. PNH treatment in the U.S. changed dramatically in 2007 when the FDA approved the first drug to treat the disorder. Since then, PNH treatments have mostly focused on targeting the complement system, a part of your immune system with blood proteins that help you fight infections and disease.

sections.heading: Eculizumab (Soliris)
content: In 2007, the FDA approved eculizumab . The monoclonal antibody is a C5 inhibitor because it blocks complement protein C5 that destroys red blood cells. (A monoclonal antibody is a protein made in a lab that acts like the antibodies already in your immune system that defend you from infections). Eculizumab stops red blood cells from breaking down inside and outside of blood vessels, but it doesn’t always work well on the outside of the blood vessels for some people. As a result, you could still develop anemia and may need blood transfusions. Still, eculizumab works well for many people and can lower the risk for thrombosis and improve your quality of life. In 2018, the FDA approved a long-acting C5 inhibitor called ravulizumab (Ultomiris). Both medicines are given by infusion into your vein with a needle.

content_blocks.text: In 2007, the FDA approved eculizumab . The monoclonal antibody is a C5 inhibitor because it blocks complement protein C5 that destroys red blood cells. (A monoclonal antibody is a protein made in a lab that acts like the antibodies already in your immune system that defend you from infections). Eculizumab stops red blood cells from breaking down inside and outside of blood vessels, but it doesn’t always work well on the outside of the blood vessels for some people. As a result, you could still develop anemia and may need blood transfusions. Still, eculizumab works well for many people and can lower the risk for thrombosis and improve your quality of life. In 2018, the FDA approved a long-acting C5 inhibitor called ravulizumab (Ultomiris). Both medicines are given by infusion into your vein with a needle.

sections.heading: Pegcetacoplan (Empaveli)
content: In 2021, the FDA approved pegcetacoplan. The monoclonal antibody infusion was the first C3 inhibitor approved in the U.S. Pegcetacoplan targets the complement protein C3, which can destroy red blood cells. The C3 inhibitor can help people who don’t respond to C5 inhibitors. It can stop red blood cells from breaking down inside and outside of the blood vessels. As a result, it works well for those who don't respond to eculizumab. The drug is injected, but you can be taught how to do it at home.

content_blocks.text: In 2021, the FDA approved pegcetacoplan. The C3 inhibitor can help people who don’t respond to C5 inhibitors. It can stop red blood cells from breaking down inside and outside of the blood vessels. As a result, it works well for those who don't respond to eculizumab. The drug is injected, but you can be taught how to do it at home.

sections.heading: Iptacopan (Fabhalta)
content: The FDA approved iptacopan in 2023. The drug is the first oral monotherapy for PNH. It’s known as a factor B complement inhibitor and targets the complement system. It stops red blood cells from being destroyed inside and outside of blood vessels. In a trial, it helped ease fatigue and improve hemoglobin levels.

sections.heading: Vaccines and PNH Treatment
content: You may be more likely to get an infection if you have PNH. For example, some people with PNH have had more red blood cell breakdown after getting a flu shot.

content_blocks.text: You may be more likely to get an infection if you have PNH. For example, some people with PNH have had more red blood cell breakdown after getting a flu shot.

content: The same may be the case if you get a COVID-19 vaccine, but supportive therapies can help with any temporary side effects. A 2022 report suggested that people taking C5 complement inhibitors should get their COVID-19 shot within days before or after their infusion. If you’re taking a complement inhibitor, you may have a higher risk for meningococcal disease. The CDC still recommends getting a meningococcal vaccine. Your doctor can advise you which vaccines are best and when to get them.

content_blocks.text: The same may be the case if you get a COVID-19 vaccine, but supportive therapies can help with any temporary side effects. A 2022 report suggested that people taking C5 complement inhibitors should get their COVID-19 shot within days before or after their infusion. If you’re taking a complement inhibitor, you may have a higher risk for meningococcal disease. The CDC still recommends getting a meningococcal vaccine. Your doctor can advise you which vaccines are best and when to get them.

sections.heading: What’s Next in PNH Treatment
content: Several drugs are being developed to treat PNH. Danicopan (Voydeya) is one of them. The oral drug works to stop factor D, a protein that plays a part in the complement system. Danicopan is a drug that you add on if you’re already taking eculizumab or ravulizumab. Your doctor may suggest adding it if you didn’t respond well to ravulizumab or eculizumab. The FDA approved danicopan under its Breakthrough Therapy designation. This means the FDA will try to approve it sooner than usual. At the time of publication, the FDA was reviewing the license for crovalimab. If approved, it would be the first monthly injection for PNH. You’ll be able to give this monoclonal antibody to yourself and not have to go to a clinic to receive the treatment.
